header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: One Precept Part 3

central_thesis: The text posits that a single, foundational precept – dedicating all one's free time beyond basic survival to working for the public good and helping all created beings – is the most direct and potent path to achieving spiritual transformation, genuine altruism ('for its own sake'), and ultimate affinity with the Creator, even surpassing the observance of numerous precepts motivated by self-love.

structure_content.summary: Rav Ashlag, through Meir Yeshurun, issues a call to young Israelites to re-engage with spiritual work and faith by adopting a minimal, yet profoundly impactful, precept: dedicating all free time beyond personal survival to working for the public good and assisting all those in need. This approach avoids the demand for immediate total acceptance of all Torah precepts, focusing instead on a single, accessible commitment.

structure_content.chapter_title: Virtues of Service and 'For Its Own Sake'
structure_content.summary: The document elaborates on the two primary virtues of serving people according to the Creator's precepts. First, it is a universally recognized and approved form of ethical conduct. Second, and crucially, this specific precept is presented as a superior 'instrument' for achieving spiritual work 'for its own sake' (Lishma), more effective than performing all 613 precepts if done out of self-love. It prepares the individual to fulfill precepts with pure intention, for the Creator's sake, not for personal benefit.

structure_content.chapter_title: Interpersonal vs. Divine Relationships in Torah
structure_content.summary: The Torah is divided into precepts concerning the relationship between a person and their friend, and between a person and Providence. The text emphasizes engaging with and accepting the former (interpersonal ethics) as a prerequisite and pathway. By mastering the relationship 'between a person and his friend,' one naturally progresses to fulfilling the relationship 'between a person and the Providence.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Speech, Thought, Action in the One Precept
structure_content.summary: The 'One Precept' must manifest across all three modalities: Thought, Speech, and Action. Action is the commitment of free time to public good. Thought is the crucial intention behind the action, focusing entirely on giving pleasure to the Maker and creating affinity. Speech involves praying and contemplating to transform the heart from a desire to receive for oneself to a desire to share, and to contemplate Torah that fosters this transformation.

Performing good deeds with the correct intention (Thought) leads to 'Affinity' with the Creator, mirroring His attributes of compassion and sharing. This process brings about a fundamental spiritual 'Transformation' from a receiving to a sharing nature, purifying the individual. This transformed state, likened to a 'negative template' or 'stamp,' then makes one fit for receiving true 'Supernal abundance' (Shefa), aligning the inner form with spirituality and holiness.

key_concepts.definition: The singular, foundational commitment to dedicate all free time beyond basic survival needs to working for the public good, assisting the depressed, the ill, and any creature needing rescue or benefit. It serves as a concentrated entry point into spiritual work.

Performing spiritual actions and precepts with the sole, pure intention of giving pleasure to the Creator and fostering affinity with Him, entirely devoid of self-interest, personal gain, or self-love. It is the ultimate goal of spiritual work.

A state of spiritual resemblance or alignment with the Creator, achieved by actively embodying His attributes of compassion, sharing, and bestowal through one's actions, thoughts, and speech. It signifies a likeness of form with the Divine.

The core spiritual metamorphosis where an individual shifts their fundamental desire from receiving for oneself (egoism) to giving and sharing for the sake of the Creator and others (altruism). This is the key to spiritual elevation and drawing closer to the Divine.

The three interconnected modalities through which spiritual work is actualized. 'Thought' is the internal intention, 'Speech' is prayer, contemplation, and study focused on transformation, and 'Action' is the physical execution of deeds, primarily selfless service in this context.

practical_system.description: The practical system revolves around the 'One Precept' as a singular, encompassing spiritual practice. It demands the dedication of all discretionary time (beyond meeting essential survival needs) to selfless service for the good of all created beings. This outward action must be internally animated by the conscious 'Thought' of giving pleasure to the Creator and cultivating 'Affinity' with His attributes of sharing and compassion. This ethical action, driven by pure intention, is believed to trigger a fundamental 'Transformation' of the practitioner's inner being from an ego-centric 'receiving' nature to an altruistic 'sharing' nature. The 'Speech' component involves constant prayer and contemplation during these service hours, explicitly asking for this internal transformation, thereby reinforcing the intention.
tools: Discretionary time (beyond basic necessities) allocated to public good and service.
Conscious intention (Thought) focused on giving pleasure to the Creator and creating affinity with His attributes.
Prayer and contemplation (Speech) as a means to invoke the Creator's aid in transforming the heart from a receiving nature to a sharing nature.
Engagement with the precepts 'between a person and his friend' (ethical interpersonal conduct) as the gateway to spiritual work.
rituals: Dedication of all free time to public service (e.g., helping the sick, depressed, or any creature in need). This continuous act of selfless bestowal, imbued with the intent to please the Creator, serves as the primary and ongoing 'ritual' of the system.

Conscious cultivation of the 'Thought' behind every act of service: 'I am doing this only to give pleasure to my Maker, and to create affinity to His ways.' This internal alignment is a continuous ritualistic practice of mindfulness and intention.

relevant_quotes.text: Therefore I have come out with this call to the young Israelites to return to the [spiritual] work [that was given] by God and to the faith in Him in a minimal fashion... but that each and every one would at any rate accept one precept.

And therefore I say that the first and only precept that would be a safer choice for one who wishes to achieve 'for its own sake' is not to take the work upon himself except for the minimum requirements to live; That is, to say exactly to the point of only providing one's own survival. And the rest of the time one should be working for the public, to help the depressed and the ill, and every creature in the world that needs rescue or simply some benefit.
It is possible that this precept is a better instrument to bring us to keep the Torah and the precepts for its own sake, than performing all the 613 precepts if they are done because of self love.
The practical idea behind taking on One Precept has already been clarified, which is that one would commit himself to dedicate all his free time for the good of all created beings in the world.

Therefore, each and every one must think in his mind that he is doing this only in order to give pleasure to his Maker, and to create affinity to His ways: 'just as He is compassionate, so should we be compassionate; just as He always shares good onto others, so should we'; and so on.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text offers a practical and accessible entry point into Kabbalistic spirituality, distilling complex ethical and religious obligations into a singular, actionable precept. It is highly relevant for modern practitioners seeking to integrate spiritual intent with altruistic action, particularly within the framework of ethical monotheism. Its emphasis on 'Lishma' (for its own sake) provides a critical lens for evaluating the efficacy of any spiritual practice, aligning it closely with higher magical ethics that prioritize alignment with divine will over personal gain. It bridges the gap between traditional religious observance and a deeply personal, transformative spiritual journey, making it a valuable resource for those who might find extensive ritual or study daunting.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Primarily aimed at 'young Israelites' as a re-engagement strategy, the text's principles are universally applicable to anyone seeking spiritual growth through ethical conduct. This includes students of Kabbalah, spiritual practitioners from various esoteric traditions, and especially magicians or occultists interested in integrating altruism and divine intention into their operative work. It appeals to those who prioritize ethical transformation and heart-centered practice over purely ceremonial or intellectual engagement.
